ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: develop much stronger speaking, reading, and writing skills
Reading comprehension, oral mastery, and appreciation of disparate cultures.
Learned a lot of vocabulary and a lot more fluency
learned a lot of new information about the spanish speaking world, including complex themes like capitalism and environmentalism. learned a lot more grammar syntax and linguistic structures.
I gained a new understanding of Spanish and Latin American culture linguistically and socially.
I developed my Spanish speaking skills and found myself able to discuss complex and interesting topics.
We went over a lot of the content from span 120 that I had felt we rushed through. We learned a lot more about cultural aspects of various Spanish-speaking countries.

Became a lot more comfortable with speaking, listening, writing, and reading Spanish at a beginner's level. Now feel equipped with to handle basic conversations in Spanish with a wide range of vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: more asynchronous days
Great class discussions that really help you to become more confident speaking the language. No judgement and a positive learning environment.

Strengths: constant in class-engagement and deep dive into the cultural aspects of Spanish Speaking countries. Great class.

Weaknesses: less emphasis on mastery of vocabulary then would have liked.
Noelia is an amazing instructor. Labor intensive but worth it because shes actually very intentional about your improvement

The course content focuses too much on context and it doesn't give us the capacity to practice the skills and grammar addressed in any given unit because there's too much focus on discussing something in depth the way we would be required to in an English literature class. It does develop, slowly, the skill to discuss something deeper than surface level, but I think the course could be better if more class time was spent on establishing a more solid foundation of knowledge and practicing skills before jumping into applying them in complex context.

- strengths: everyone participated, interesting themes
- weaknesses: a lot of work
I really loved how project-based this course was. I think that the supersite felt unnecessary in the learning process.

Strengths: the course is great, but Prof Sanchez-Walker is phenomenal. I dont think I could have had such a great experience without her as my professor. She was so excited to see the students engaging and learning with one another, it was great.
Weaknesses: I truly think if tenses were split between Span 120 and Span 130 they could be learned more successfully. It would allow for a more concrete understanding if more time was spent on every tense instead of running through them and then backtracking the next semester.

Strengths: Professor is very nice, supportive, and helpful for helping develop Spanish skills. There is a good balance of vocabulary that we have already learned and new vocabulary mixed in every lesson. The course starts at the beginning of a Spanish textbook unlike SPAN 120, so all basic concepts are reviewed and more advanced uses of them are covered. Weaknesses: I know that the course being labor-intensive is part of what helps me develop language skills but there were times where the amount of homework felt like busy work. The worksheets seem designed to be completed in-class but there were often times when they were assigned as homework in addition to another worksheet.

I wish the long-term schedule for the course was road-mapped at the start. Whenever an exam happened, it always felt like we only ever had around a week of notice. There is also somewhat of a disconnect between the content learned in VHL Central and what we actually end up using in class. It felt like VHL Central covered grammar beyond what we were expected to know and use in-class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this course! Professor Sanchez-Walker is a wonderful person and an engaging instructor. She always made herself available for office hours, and I felt supported throughout the course. I liked that the lessons incorporated different types of material from the Spanish world.
The professor is great! I learned current issues and their impact away from domestic United States and explored their impact in Spanish-Speaking countries.
Yes if you want to take spanish
Yes, if you need to take spanish or want to move past learning about grammar and put things in context.
I loved this course, and professor Sanchez Walker is most definitely the reason. She is such an incredible teacher and makes hiking up five flights of stairs worth it.
I would absolutely recommend this course especially with Prof SW, she is fantastic and is amazing to see in class each day.
Yes, if you are somewhat comfortable in Spanish this is a great choice as it covers Spanish concepts from the very start. It goes at a pace that lets you review prerequisite content as needed.
